that the award was insufficiently stamped and (b) that the award was not registered. He also alleged that the Arbitrator was guilty of legal misconduct, and that award was given beyond time. These objections were replied to by the respondents.

anchor.surface_text: If the whole of the subject-matter of the companypromise is within the reference, the Court may include in the operative part of the decree the award as modified. But if it is number so, the Court may companyfine the operative part of the decree to the award as far as accepted, and the other terms of settlement which form a part thereof, if severable and within the original reference, in a schedule to the decree.

arguments.claim: parties can supersede reference under s.5 and s.12(2)(b) if compromise beyond award

holdings.text: The power to record a compromise modifying an arbitration award and to make it a part of the decree follows from the application of the Code of Civil Procedure by s. 41 of the Arbitration Act and s. 141 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: from the application of the Code of Civil Procedure, by s. 41 of the Arbitration Act and also s. 141 of the Code. It only remains to point out that in a reference without the intervention of the Court, the Court has no general jurisdiction over the subject-matter as in a reference in a pending suit. If the submission is superseded in the former,

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.41 subjects to Act provisions but allows O.23 r.3 as procedural; no bar in ss.15,30,32; policy favors settlements; analogous to Hemanta Kumari PC case allowing compromise in decree operative or schedule.

holdings.text: If the whole subject-matter of the compromise is within the reference, include modified award in operative part of decree; if not entirely, operative part award as accepted, severable terms in schedule.

anchor.surface_text: If the whole of the subject-matter of the compromise is within the reference, the Court may include in the operative part of the decree the award as modified. But if it is not so, the Court may confine the operative part of the decree to the award as far as accepted, and the other terms of settlement which form a part thereof, if severable and within the original reference, in a schedule to the decree.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Privy Council in Hemanta Kumari; distinguishes full modification within scope from partial; schedule enforceable as contract evidenced by decree.

holdings.text: Parties may revoke submission under s.5 and supersede agreement under s.12(2)(b) if compromise goes beyond award scope, allowing decree per compromise.

anchor.surface_text: the Court could give leave to the parties to revoke a submission under s. 5 of the Arbitration Act, and on superseding the arbitration agreement thereafter under s. 12 (2) (b), pass a decree in terms of the compromise.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Good cause for revocation includes compromise; supersession ends arbitration, court passes decree on new terms.

holdings.text: In the present case, the compromise quantified income-tax per award direction and altered payment mode, within reference; decree properly framed and not a nullity.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the decree on the award was properly framed, because the award made room for adjustment of the income-tax, ordering that the income-tax, when assessed, would be borne equally by the three parties, and the compromise merely worked out that direction by reducing the amounts payable to the two respondents by Rs. 4,000/- each.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Compromise direct consequence of award; quantified unassessed tax equally shared; mode change allowable by consent.

holdings.text: Cases under Arbitration Act 1899 inapplicable as no power to pass decree existed then, unlike present Act.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 15 of that Act, the Court was not required to pronounce a judgment or pass a decree, since the Act did not contain any provision for passing a decree.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes prior law where award executable per se without decree; present Act mandates judgment and decree, allowing modification scope.

holdings.text: The decree is not a nullity due to the compromise modification.

anchor.surface_text: There is nothing in the Arbitration Act, which disentitles the court from taking notice of an agreement of this character, and, in our opinion, the decree cannot be characterised as a nullity on this ground.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No disentitling provision; upheld lower findings on stamp remedy and copy admissibility implicitly by dismissing appeal.

anchor.surface_text: If the whole of the subject-matter of the compromise is within the reference, the Court may include in the operative part of the decree the award as modified.
